key_insight: A multimodal Early Warning Index (EWI) converts heterogeneous clinical and operational data into timely, interpretable risk scores that flag patients at risk of deterioration earlier than standard monitoring alone.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between disparate hospital data streams and actionable clinical alerts by automatically harmonizing varied formats to produce accurate, clinician-friendly predictions of patient deterioration.
method: Harmonize and preprocess heterogeneous data (vitals, labs, notes, device/operational signals) into a unified feature set for modeling.
Train multimodal machine‑learning models that emphasize early detection, calibration, and interpretability (risk score + feature attributions).
Validate retrospectively and simulate real‑time deployment using time‑to‑event metrics and operational feasibility checks to ensure clinically actionable lead times.
impact: Provides a practical blueprint for building interoperable, explainable early warning systems in hospitals; useful for ML practitioners working on clinical deployments, data integration, and trustworthy AI.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing heterogeneous inputs → harmonization → multimodal model → interpretable risk score
Timeline chart comparing warning lead time of the EWI versus standard monitoring before deterioration events
Feature importance / attribution bar chart highlighting top drivers of risk for a sample patient
Mock clinician dashboard showing patient risk score, trend, and brief explanation for the alert
paper_title: Early Warning Index for Patient Deteriorations in Hospitals
paper_authors: Dimitris Bertsimas, Yu Ma, Kimberly Villalobos Carballo, Gagan Singh, Michal Laskowski
